title: 106_hr2651
content: The Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999 Act, also known as the "Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999," includes sections on eliminating restrictions on physician referrals based on compensation arrangements, exceptions to ownership referral prohibitions, changes in the definition of group practice, and other related provisions. Eliminating restrictions on physician referrals based on compensation arrangements is addressed in the Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999 Act. The Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999 Act amended Section 1877 of the Social Security Act to allow ownership or investment interest in entities through equity, with exceptions for publicly traded securities and mutual funds. The Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999 Act amended Section 1877 of the Social Security Act to allow ownership or investment interest in entities through equity, with exceptions for publicly traded securities and mutual funds. The Act also made changes to subsections (c) and (d) by redesignating paragraphs and amending headings. The Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999 Act amended Section 1877 of the Social Security Act by redesignating paragraphs and amending subsections, including striking subsection (e) and making changes to subsection (f) regarding ownership and investment interests. The Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999 Act made changes to subsection (h) by removing paragraphs (1), (2), and (3), modifying rules for faculty, and adjusting ownership and investment interests. SEC. 3. EXCEPTIONS TO OWNERSHIP REFERRAL PROHIBITIONS. Revisions to Exception for In-Office Ancillary Services include repealing the site-of-service requirement and defining general supervision for individuals under a physician in the group practice. The amendment clarifies that an individual is under general supervision of a physician in a group practice if the physician is legally responsible for the services provided, regardless of physical presence. It also addresses the treatment of physician owners in group practices. The amendment clarifies that a physician in a group practice is legally responsible for services provided under general supervision, regardless of physical presence. It also addresses the treatment of physician owners in group practices. The amendment clarifies that a physician in a group practice is legally responsible for services provided under general supervision, regardless of physical presence. It also addresses the treatment of physician owners in group practices. Section 1877(d)(2) of the Act is amended to require "not less than 75 percent" of services to be furnished in a rural area. The amendment changes the definition of group practice to include physicians who are owners or bona fide employees of the group. Additionally, there is a delay in implementing ownership referral changes until final regulations are issued. SEC. 5 delays implementation of 1993 ownership referral changes until final regulations are issued. SEC. 6 excludes intraocular lenses, eyeglasses, and contact lenses. SEC. 7 allows supervision of clinical laboratory services by independent contractor pathologists. Section 1877(h)(6)(H) of the Social Security Act is amended to exclude intraocular lenses, eyeglasses, and contact lenses. Pathologists who supervise clinical laboratory services for a group practice are deemed to be members of that group practice. The amendments apply to referrals made after the enactment of the Act.
